name.text: 001 Watch the video: Sequences, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

questiontext.text: Watch the video: Sequences, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

name.text: 002 Sequences are powerful because:

questiontext.text: Sequences are powerful because:

answer.text: They let you refer to an entire collection, as well as the items in the collection, using a single name.
They let you iterate and facilitate the creation of terminating loops.
They make Python a Turing Complete language.

name.text:

sequence = [74, 34, 13, 30, 4004]

name.text: 006 Choose the expression that represents the first item in a sequence named seq:

questiontext.text: Choose the expression that represents the first item in a sequence named seq:

name.text: 007 Choose the expression that represents the last item in a sequence named seq:

questiontext.text: Choose the expression that represents the last item in a sequence named seq:

name.text:
008 Given that seq is a sequence, what is the result of the expression 
seq[len(seq)]

questiontext.text:
Given that seq is a sequence, what is the result of the expression 
seq[len(seq)]

answer.text: The result is the last item of the sequence.
The result is the length of the sequence.

name.text:
009 A fellow student turns to you and says "I don't understand why my code is giving me an error on this line: 
s[len(s)] = 40
I used len(s) before in my FOR loop and it seemed to work just fine!" The FOR loop to which they referred is: 
for k in range(len(s)): 
         s[k] = k
What do you tell them to explain why their statement 
s[len(s)] = 30
is wrong?

questiontext.text:
A fellow student turns to you and says "I don't understand why my code is giving me an error on this line: 
s[len(s)] = 40
I used len(s) before in my FOR loop and it seemed to work just fine!" The FOR loop to which they referred is: 
for k in range(len(s)): 
         s[k] = k
What do you tell them to explain why their statement 
s[len(s)] = 30
is wrong?

answer.text: Previously you used len(s) as an argument to the RANGE function. The last value that the RANGE function yields is the argument - 1 so you accessed the last element in the sequence at index len(s) - 1. The index len(s) is actually one past the end of the sequence!
I don't know, all of your code seems valid. There is probably a problem with Eclipse.
You probably changed the length of the sequence s sometime between when you used it in your FOR loop and when you later access an element with the code s[len(s)].
You can only use a number for the index of a sequence and len(s) is not a number.

name.text: 010 Do the reading on using the RANGE function (see the Session 11 Preparation page). Then watch the video: Iterating Through Sequences, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

  • It returns the sum of the numbers in the sequence.

018 Implement a function named count_positives for which:
  • Its sole argument is a sequence of integers.
  • It returns the number of integers in the sequence that are positive.

name.text: 019 Do the reading: Computing & Society 6.1 Computer Viruses, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

questiontext.text: Do the reading: Computing & Society 6.1 Computer Viruses, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

name.text: 020 In November 1988, Robert Morris launched a computer virus (actually, a form of virus called a worm) that, through an error in his code, delivered a denial-of-service attack to computers on the Internet. His worm worked by attacking a program called finger that was written in the programming language C. If finger had been written and run in Python, his attack would NOT have succeeded.

questiontext.text: In November 1988, Robert Morris launched a computer virus (actually, a form of virus called a worm) that, through an error in his code, delivered a denial-of-service attack to computers on the Internet. His worm worked by attacking a program called finger that was written in the programming language C. If finger had been written and run in Python, his attack would NOT have succeeded.

name.text: 021 Very briefly, explain your answer to the previous problem.

questiontext.text: Very briefly, explain your answer to the previous problem.

name.text: 022 Morris was convicted under The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. After appeal, what was his sentence?

questiontext.text: Morris was convicted under The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. After appeal, what was his sentence?

name.text: 023 In your own opinion, do you feel that his sentence was: [you get full credit for ANY answer here, even though Moodle will probably mark your answer as "wrong"; just select what best fits YOUR opinion]

questiontext.text: In your own opinion, do you feel that his sentence was: [you get full credit for ANY answer here, even though Moodle will probably mark your answer as "wrong"; just select what best fits YOUR opinion]

answer.text: A lot too leniant (i.e., he should have gotten a heavier sentence -- jail time, or a longer probation, or more required community service, or a larger fine, or some combination of those)
A lot too severe (i.e., he should have gotten a lighter sentence -- a shorter probation, or less required community service, or a smaller fine, or some combination of those)

name.text: 024 Very briefly, explain your answer to the previous problem.

questiontext.text: Very briefly, explain your answer to the previous problem.
